sections.title: ClickPad
sections.content: The only tweak you may want is to resize active area. With default config, you can cosily use as pointer only top 1/3 of ClickPad. See Touchpad Synaptics#Buttonless touchpads (aka ClickPads) for instructions.

sections.title: Keyboard
sections.content:
Fn and Ctrl keys can be swapped in BIOS.

Fn lock can be switched with Fn+Esc.

sections.title: Backlight
sections.content: Backlight control works with multimedia keys (Fn+F5/Fn+F6). To configure brightness level on startup see Backlight#Udev rule.

sections.title: Audio
sections.content: Default configuration could point to non-existent device because numbering of HDMI devices does not start with 0. Suggested solution is to set PCH device to default by placing a configuration file into /etc/modprobe.d. The following thread contains alternative solutions and detailed instructions: Fixing ALSA device selection.

sections.title: With Fn and Ctrl_L keys swapped, Ctrl_L+s hotkey is mapped to Alt_L
sections.content:
Lenovo Forums topic

Issue is present on notebooks with BIOS versions older than v2.16. Problem can be solved with a BIOS update up to v2.16 or newer. See the BIOS v2.16 update changelog.

sections.title: Blinking power LED after resume from suspend
sections.content:
This is not a real problem, but can be annoying and has a very simple solution:

```
# echo "0 on" > /proc/acpi/ibm/led
```

For automation, create a script depending on the used power management tool.

sections.title: BIOS Update
sections.content:
Steps below were tested by contributors of this page and work perfectly. However, do the following procedure at your own risk!

To update the BIOS from a USB drive, follow these steps (alternatively, you can download the ISO, burn it to a CD, and then boot from the CD):

1. Download the latest firmware from the official E440 Downloads page (search for "BIOS Update (Bootable CD) for Windows").
1. Install the geteltoritoAUR utility.
1. Convert ISO image: $ geteltorito.pl -o bios.img j9ujXXwd.iso
1. Write the image to the USB drive. Suppose, your drive is /dev/sdb. Warning: all information on USB stick will be lost! Unmount all partitions associated to the drive (perform for every existing 'X'): # umount /dev/sdbX Write image: # dd if=bios.img of=/dev/sdb bs=1M
1. Reboot you PC and boot from your USB drive.
1. FOLLOW ALL INSTRUCTIONS written in the update utility!

```
$ geteltorito.pl -o bios.img j9ujXXwd.iso
```

1. Unmount all partitions associated to the drive (perform for every existing 'X'): # umount /dev/sdbX
1. Write image: # dd if=bios.img of=/dev/sdb bs=1M

```
# umount /dev/sdbX
```

```
# dd if=bios.img of=/dev/sdb bs=1M
```
